22.text:
Welcome to Ieper [Ypres] in Belgium. Now,
I’m standing in the Grand Place.

26.text: Now at first sight if you look round, it looks like any of these magnificent squares you find in Belgian

31.text:
towns representing, perhaps, 800 years or
more, of architectural history. You find squares

36.text:
like this in Antwerp, in Ghent, in Bruges,
in Brussels itself. But this square, here

40.text:
in Ieper, is different: the reason is, this
square has been lovingly rebuilt, recreated,

46.text:
brick-by-brick, stone-by-stone; indeed, the
whole town of Ieper has been rebuilt.

51.text: And that’s because this town was utterly destroyed during the five great battles of Ypres, which were

57.text:
fought round here during the First World War
between 1914 and 1918. Now, of course, there

63.text:
were 250,000 casualties in those battles - many
thousands of them coming from Yorkshire.

68.text:
And today, we’re going to try and trace
where they fought, how and why they died.

73.text:
And our guide is Jacques Ryckebosch, and the
first thing I should ask you, I suppose is,

78.text:
why the town was rebuilt. Many wanted to
leave it as a living memorial, didn’t they?

83.text: The whole idea was to rebuild Ieper on another site and leave this beautiful little town

88.text:
as a memorial of what happened here during
the First World War. One of the main reasons

93.text:
why Ieper was rebuilt, was the population
of Ieper, who had fled, returned after the

98.text:
First World War, learned about the plans of
leaving it in ruins and they said: ‘We want

103.text:
our houses back; we want our churches back;
we want the Cloth Hall back; we want the Cathedral

108.text:
back. I’m saying this in a few seconds - it
was not easy at all. But they did it.

113.text:
They did, as you said, lovingly. The beautiful thing
is, that even they kept names of restaurants.

120.text:
So, the few restaurants, here on the square,
and the names are just the same as they were

125.text:
before the First World War. Generally speaking,
how important a part did Yorkshire Regiments,

129.text:
Yorkshire soldiers, play in the battles here?
A very important part. When you look at the

133.text:
various battles they were in, then you realise
they were in many main battles and very important

140.text:
battles, just as defence, this little town,
Ieper, and to prevent the Germans would through Ieper

146.text:
and to the ports of Dunkirk, Calais and
Boulogne. So, they played, indeed, a very very

151.text:
important role. We’re now in the centre
of Ieper, we need to go to those battlefields

155.text:
to see where they fought, where they died.
Where are we going first? Essex Farm,

164.text: Essex Farm lies a mile to the north of Ieper. It was an advance dressing station.

169.text:
This is where wounded soldiers
were evacuated from the front line.

174.text: If they were lucky, they would be treated and passed further back.

179.text: Well Jacques this is Essex Farm. It is, yes. And this part here was an advance dressing station. Is it then an indication that we are

185.text:
some way back from the front line? From here,
we were about 3,000 yards [2,743 metres] behind

190.text:
the front lines - although the lines were
converging very very rapidly towards the canal.

194.text:
So, during the First World War there was an
evacuation system for wounded soldiers - a chain.

199.text:
At the front line, you had what was called RAPs
- Regimental Aid Posts - the soldier was checked-out.

206.text:
If it was serious he was taken to an advance
dressing station - an ADS. An ADS was normally

212.text:
situated, let’s say it varied, say, 3,000-4,000
yards behind the front line. I have to say

218.text:
the ADS, you see now, was built late 1916.
Before that, it was just a dug out in earth.

226.text:
And I have here a description of a soldier,
who gives actually a very god description

230.text:
about what these dug outs looked like before
late December, late 1916. It goes as follows:

238.text:
‘We took up our residence in some crazy
dug outs on the Yser canal, which we crossed

243.text:
by a pontoon bridge. The dug outs were not
even splinter proof, nor shelter us from the

249.text:
sun, and along the top of the bank ran a trench
into which we were ordered to shelter whenever

253.text:
shelling started. There is plenty of water
in the canal, although it is more or less

258.text:
stagnant. It breeds clouds of mosquitos which
bite like fun. Although it is nice to be able

263.text:
to get a wash when one likes, there are too
many floating carcasses of various sorts’.

269.text:
Now, this is something I wasn’t expecting:
the poem ‘In Flanders Fields’ by John

275.text:
McCrae. Now, tell me a bit about him, was
he… he was a doctor I think. He was a doctor

281.text:
and he worked here April-May 1915 during the
Second Battle of Ypres. So, when John McCrae

287.text:
arrived here, there were dug outs, but not
in concrete - in earth. And John McCrae worked

293.text:
here as a doctor and on the 2nd May 1915 he
lost one of his best friends, that was Lieutenant

299.text:
Alexis Helmer. Alexis Helmer got hit by a
shell, obviously killed, and was buried in

304.text:
the cemetery at Essex Farm. He’s now actually
mentioned on the Menin Gate in Ieper.

309.text: The last words in his dairy, of Alexis Helmer, were: ‘It has quieted a little, and I shall

315.text:
try and get a good sleep’. And, a few hours
later he was dead. John McCrae lost a very

320.text:
very dear friend. And the following day,
3rd May 1915, he sat here somewhere, and he

326.text:
wrote that famous poem. The poem was published
for the first time ever on the 8th December

331.text:
1915 in a British magazine called ‘Punch’.
It was published anonymously. And on the 28th…

338.text:
29th December 1915, Punch magazine published
all the names of the poets who had contributed

345.text:
to the magazine, and, I have to say, they
made a mistake! Instead of McCrae they printed

348.text:
McCree. Obviously, everybody realised that
it was Dr John McCrae who had written the

354.text:
poem. It’s very sad in a way; John McCrae
did not survive the war. After the Second

360.text:
Battle of Ypres, he was moved to a base hospital
in France, Boulogne-sur-Mer Wimereux. Despite

365.text:
his high rank, he was Lieutenant Colonel,
he kept on staying with his men. He kept staying

372.text:
in tents and refused better accommodation.
His whole life he had been an asthma patient

378.text: and in January 1918 he got a mix of meningitis / pneumonia and he passed away on the 28th January 1918.

386.text:
It is still a deeply moving poem, and perhaps
we should just read it through:

392.text: In Flanders fields the poppies blow, Between the crosses; row on row, That mark our place; and in the

398.text:
sky the larks, still bravely singing, fly
scarce heard amid the guns below. We are the Dead.

405.text:
Short days ago we lived, felt dawn,
saw sunset glow, loved and were loved, and

412.text:
now we lie in Flanders fields. Take up our
quarrel with the foe:

417.text:
to you from failing hands we throw the torch;
be yours to hold it high. If ye break faith

424.text:
with us who die we shall not sleep, though
poppies grow in Flanders fields.

440.text: It is a moving experience to stand where the poem was written - to imagine the noise, the smell, the ravaged

446.text:
land, and the cries of the wounded. This is
a Spring day and coaches are arriving bringing

453.text:
youngsters from around Europe. Schools as
well as uniform groups.

459.text: They are making the same pilgrimage as countless thousands of others

463.text: since the war ended over 90 years ago.

472.text:
Well this is a very prominent memorial to
the men of the 49th West Riding Division who

478.text:
died on the salient. It’s a magnificent
and a very large memorial. How come they got

484.text:
one and perhaps other divisions, battalions, didn’t?
Well, that Regiment held the line here in

489.text:
1915/1916. And they had a very dubious honour,
together with the 6th Division, to be great

497.text:
victims of the first German gas attacks with
Fortean gas, and that was the 19th December 1916.

504.text:
Also, they had the winter of 1916, and
in the records you can read that there were

512.text:
400 cases of severe trench foot - and it’s
horrible when you read it - it is written

517.text:
that their feet were swollen like soccer balls.
So not only they suffered very badly from

522.text:
gas attacks, Fortean gas, but also the harsh
winter of 1916. So they held and defended

529.text:
this line, which was extremely heavily shelled
by the Germans. So, obviously, with this memorial,

533.text:
there are no individual names, but, presumably,
there are many soldiers who died, from that

538.text:
West Yorkshire Division, buried down here
in the cemetery? Unfortunately they are.

541.text: They are buried in plots 1 of the cemetery. Perhaps, we ought to go and pay our respects, before we move on.

550.text:
Look along the row of graves;
how young these soldiers were who gave their lives -

555.text:
20, 21, 22. The youngest in the cemetery
is 15 years-old.

561.text: Many of them died on the same day - the 4th June 1916, when German shelling reached a new intensity to

568.text: cover the retreat at the end of the First Battle of Ypres.

571.text: Now it’s interesting, because some of these stones

574.text: have little epitaphs on the bottom and some don’t.

577.text:
There’s a story behind that, isn’t there? There
is actually; some families did not want to

581.text:
have an epitaph, but, the other reason is,
the family had to pay for those epitaphs - even

588.text:
per letter. Some families, unfortunately,
could not afford it - so you can see some

593.text:
headstones without an epitaph. That’s really
sad, isn’t it? It is sad, yes.

597.text: But, on the other hand, you’re also telling me, that until not very long ago, most of

604.text:
these stones were so weathered you couldn’t
read the inscriptions, the names, at all.

608.text: That’s true, about, let’s say two years ago, it was very difficult to read and for

612.text:
four months and a half, rain or shine, the
stone masons of the Commonwealth War Graves

617.text:
Commission, re-engraved every headstone. Normally,
they can re-engrave four or five headstones

622.text:
a day. You have to admire their work. Now
the other thing which we need to bear in mind,

627.text: I suppose is, because it is so peaceful, it is so beautiful now, but when these men were first buried,

634.text: they were not allowed to rest in peace, even then by the Germans?

637.text: Absolutely not. And I have an account here of Harry Kendall, a soldier who was stationed here, and I think

642.text:
his account says it all. He writes, in his
diary: ‘Often a dozen times a day, they

648.text:
were smothered over with mud from the graves,
turned-up by Fritz’s exhuming shells.

653.text: Possibly the worst place of this point was by Number Four bridge, was the eternal view of dead man’s

659.text:
staring eyes. Slaughtered man laying about
in all shapes and forms around this unholy

664.text:
post of ours. Sometimes this immolated human
beings will be wrapped in army blankets tied

670.text:
around their heads and feet. At other times,
nothing but was frightful disfigurements or mutilations

676.text:
were to be seen on the faces of the bodies
of these glorious corpses’.

682.text:
But now, at least, they do rest in peace. They do. Let’s
move on now, as I think you want to show us now

687.text:
the Yorkshire trench. The Yorkshire trench.
Which is at the heart…

700.text: From Essex Farm to the Yorkshire trench is about a quarter of a mile. You cross the Yser canal to reach it.

707.text:
The trench now is incongruously sited
on an industrial estate. A reminder once that

712.text:
the pressure was on to get back to normal
as soon as the war ended.

716.text: A reminder also that just 21 years later, the Germans were once again advancing

721.text: across this same stretch of land at the beginning of World War Two.

728.text: So, right here, in the middle of a modern industrial estate

731.text: we have the Yorkshire trench, so, presumably, it was filled with Yorkshire soldiers throughout the… it was 1915/1916.

736.text: And the first thing we come across then is this sort of wooden construction.

741.text: Now what exactly is that? This is called actually an ‘A’ frame, which was used in the trenches.

746.text:
A reversed ‘A’, so on the top is some
kind of duck board where soldiers walked.

751.text:
Underneath was the gutter. The big problem
in this area is water. The water table is

758.text:
very very high. Water was always a problem;
mud, trench foot, etc. So, as soon as you

764.text:
dug down, to dug your trench, I mean, you hit water?
You hit water. When, nowadays, they found trenches,

769.text:
tunnels, dug outs; always they found water
pumps and water pipes - always.

773.text: So did the ‘A’ frames work? I mean, by-and-large did they keep the duck boards and therefore the soldiers out of the water?

779.text:
They were a great improvement.
But, when you look at photographs, for some

784.text:
periods it could be extremely wet. But, definitely
it was an improvement. Also it gave support

788.text: for the trench. Keep the walls apart - stop them caving in? Yes, that’s right, yeah.

792.text: Well, let’s move down now actually into the trench then, shall we?

812.text: So, obviously, to give permanence, these are not sandbags, they are actually concrete blocks, aren’t they?

818.text: Made to look like sandbags. So that’s the... presumably, that's the only bit, down here,

821.text: which is not authentic, is that right?

823.text:
That is correct, yes. Here we
have a dug out. So for protection soldiers

828.text:
had to go underground. Heavy calibre shells
and clay could go down up to 30ft [9 metres).

834.text: So some dug outs were 47ft, 50ft [14-15 metres], even deeper. And, so, to down there, there would have been

841.text:
little dug out areas for living and sleeping…
A little chamber there, could be a little

847.text:
headquarters - a place for the commanding
officer and staff… larger dug outs, behind

855.text:
front lines, you had sleeping bunks, etc.
So that you could stay… you had to go underground.

859.text:
Cos we were very very close to the enemy lines,
the German lines, here.

863.text: So, how long would a soldier have been in a trench… There was a rotation and, in theory, could be five days.

872.text: There were several ones of trenches. It was a rotation - five days, of course.

875.text: After a while they needed to be… de-liced; they had to have new uniforms; in winter it was very damp,

882.text:
very wet, so they needed new equipment, actually.
A veteran once said, said it in one line about

890.text:
trench warfare: ‘We live like rats and we
smell like pigs’.

896.text: My Grandad, the only thing he said about the war was,

899.text:
‘ The best remedy
against lice, why, that is a good cigar!’

903.text:
That’s all he said about the war. All he
said about trench warfare.

907.text: The other thing, of course, if they were down here, was presumably that constant fear, anticipation, dread,

913.text: that the order would come to go 'over the top' into the sights of the enemy machine guns.

918.text:
That is one aspect, but also trench life could
be very boring. But always, you had that danger

925.text:
of sniping, shelling. So you never knew what
was coming to hit you. Veterans’ told me:

933.text:
‘During the day you kept your head down
and you tried to sleep standing’.

938.text: So, all the work happened during the night. So, trenches were looked after every night. A good trench

944.text:
was a matter of life or death. Trench raids
happened during the night - everything happened

948.text:
during the night. So during the day it could
be very very very quiet.

953.text: Because you couldn’t do anything because you’d attract enemy fire if you did. Exactly! Exactly!

957.text: So trench warfare, sniping, shelling, trench raids, etc.

963.text: And, this was always, was it then manned by members of Yorkshire battalions, Yorkshire Regiments?

971.text:
Of course, this is only a little stretch of trenches.
The trenches went much further. But, as I

978.text:
said, the ‘no man’s land’ was extremely
narrow. I was going to say, how far away were

982.text:
the German lines? From here, well, a little
bit further, it was only 18 yards [16.5 meters].

986.text:
18 yards? Yes, 18 yards. You could almost
hear them talk then couldn’t you? In a way, yes!

992.text: A little bit further there was actually… Here’s Yorkshire trench, where a little bit further

996.text:
was a trench and they called it ‘International
Trench’ - because the nationality of that

1000.text:
trench changed all the time. So, sometimes
it was German, and sometimes it was the Brits?

1004.text:
Yeah. It was heavy fighting here, it
was certainly not… you could not talk about

1009.text:
a safe sector in the Ypres salient. But this
was not a safe place to be, that’s for sure.

1017.text:
From the dug out, a little further along,
and you come to a fire step. Nothing more

1021.text:
than a plate of iron with a hole through which
you could pass the muzzle of a gun.

1025.text: Jacques points out how dangerous the position was. The German guns would be aimed at this corner.

1032.text:
And just putting your head above the parapet
would be enough to seal your fate.

1046.text: The trench is unbelievably narrow - just around the corner another small cut into the trench.

1054.text:
According to Jacques this was a ‘pas de deux’ - not
a ballet dance - just a passing place.

1060.text: All the supplies were brought up along this narrow slit that zig-zagged all over the place.

1067.text:
Today, none of the mud and broken duck boards and
other detritus of war, would have made this

1077.text: I asked Jacques how far away the front line would be? The answer:

1081.text:
100 yards [91.5 metres]. It means that you
would be able to hear the Germans talking.

1086.text: If the wind was in the right direction, smell their cooking,

1090.text: if you could above the stench of the battlefield.

1100.text: There was little movement during the day - most of the action

1103.text:
took place at night, or, in the early hours
of the morning. This whole area, indeed this

1108.text:
trench, was fought over again and again, passing
from one side to the other almost continuously

1123.text: From here we head three miles to the south-east of Ieper to Hill 60.

1127.text: Not a real hill, but created from the spoil of a rail line from Comines to Ypres

1138.text: Well Jacques, I think we’re now about three miles

1140.text:
south-east of Ieper and the Yorkshire
trench where we were before.

1144.text: We’ve come to one of the most notorious spots in the Ypres salient. Definitely. Hill 60. Absolutely.

1150.text:
And this had Yorkshire involvement as well.
Tell me a bit about Hill 60.

1154.text: Hill 60 is a graveyard. There was continuous fighting for that hill: 60 metres high, 60 metres above sea level.

1161.text:
Strategically a very important
place, so, obviously, a German target.

1166.text: The French had it in 1914; the Germans took it, then the British took it, the Germans took it again

1172.text: - then it remained in German hands for about two years.

1175.text: Then the Battle of Messines, 7th June [1917] - this was most northern part of that battle

1180.text: - so the allies took it again;

1181.text:
the Germans took it again in April 1918 and
eventually, it was taken again, by the allies

1186.text:
at the end of the war. So, at what stage then
was the Yorkshire Regiment the Duke of Wellington’s

1191.text:
involved? April 1915. There was an attack
on the hill - it was quite successful - especially

1197.text:
the Second Battalion of the Duke of Wellington
Regiment - fought here very bravely.

1203.text: They were very much involved in it. It was very harsh fighting, on a very narrow frontage.

1210.text:
Lost a lot of soldiers: officers and men. But they did
their job. But, I mean, the whole war was

1217.text:
so ghastly that it’s perhaps surprising that
something even as particularly horrible here.

1223.text:
Yes. There was a lot of hand-to-hand
fighting. There was continuous tunnelling,

1228.text:
there was continuous mining. Gas was used.
Hill 60, as you said, was absolutely notorious

1236.text:
- very, very dangerous to be here. Now, the
other thing you mentioned, of course, which

1240.text:
is interesting, is tunnelling, and this is
what where, both sides, attempted to tunnel

1244.text:
under the trenches of the other side and detonate
mines, and blow then up from underneath.

1249.text: They did; especially here at Hill 60. They had a fortification, or a position, as you said,

1256.text:
dug a tunnel, there was a chamber
under that position, put it full of gun cotton

1261.text:
or anomyl, and they blew it up! So, also mentally
for the soldiers, they must have realised there

1266.text:
was always that possibility that underneath
me there was mining going on.

1274.text: Hill 60 was a place to avoid - if you could. Definitely. But the Duke of Wellington’s, those Yorkshire

1278.text:
soldiers, couldn’t avoid it, so… No. What
do we see here, it’s dips and ravines,

1283.text: and paths and craters… A lot of shell carters, mine craters, and, as I’ve said, there was

1290.text:
continuous shelling, mining… and it’s
still visible to this day.

1296.text:
It is an artificial hill, but it is absolutely a war memorial
here - the whole hill.

1301.text: But were those Yorkshire soldiers, the Duke of Wellington’s, were they in trenches here, or,

1305.text: was trench warfare not applicable in an area like this? They were trenches here; but they really charged

1313.text:
the German positions here. And they attacked
it successfully for a short period, because

1319.text:
on the 5th May 1915, the Germans, created
a gas attack. That enabled the Germans to

1329.text:
take their positions again. Well, I suppose
what in a sense is what is so tragic, looking back

1333.text:
with the virtue of hindsight is that; all that killing, all that
fighting, and, this is an area that changed

1339.text:
hands regularly throughout the war. You really
didn’t have an advantage. That is it: all for 60 metres.

1344.text:
But as you can see, the view
we have of Ieper is very important…

1362.text: From Hill 60 we head back north again to Tyne Cot Cemetery,

1367.text:
six miles to the north of Ieper.
We’re heading for Zonnebeke. This was where

1372.text:
the Third Battle of Ypres, or Passchendaele
as it was better known, was fought.

1377.text: Jacques shows me a photograph of Zonnebeke taken in 1917 - it shows it completely decimated.

1384.text:
The cemetery lies on the ridge between the
small town and the village of Passchendale itself.

1396.text:
This is Tyne Cot Cemetery it is the
largest Commonwealth War Cemetery in the world.

1401.text:
12,000 people are buried here. But, that’s
really only a small minority of the total

1407.text: number who died on both sides in the various battles around Ypres.

1412.text: Half a million people killed, missing or wounded. And what were they fighting for?

1417.text: A piece of land around the town of Ypres, four miles by four miles: 16sq miles in all.

1424.text: Well Jacques, of those half a million, it’s not really possible top say, is it, how many were actually Yorkshire soldiers?

1431.text:
It is very difficult to say actually.
Very difficult, because they were in all theatres,

1436.text:
all over the salient and other places in France,
you name it. Very difficult to say, indeed.

1442.text:
Presumably, also because all Regiments, all
the detachments, battalions, got decimated

1446.text:
and they were tagged together - were they,
to make up numbers? That’s right, absolutely.

1456.text: But all one can say is that those soldiers, from Yorkshire,

1459.text:
whichever battalion, division,
company, they were fighting for, they played

1463.text:
a very vital role here didn’t they? They
did, indeed. Absolutely. Nobody can deny that.

1468.text:
Absolutely not. But yet, on the other hand,
16 sq miles, what they were fighting for,

1472.text:
how can one possibly say it was worth it?
Well… xxx the Ypres salient and Ieper, the

1481.text:
town of Ieper, became a symbol of their tenacity.
And they paid a very high price for not allowing

1490.text:
the Germans not to take Ieper. They paid a very
high price for it. But, they were one of the

1496.text:
very many who prevented it. But, perhaps,
after all, above all, if you take a step back

1501.text:
- it is just the foliy of war, the cruelty
of war, isn’t it? It is, absolutely, yes.

1507.text: Well Jacques, thank you for all your time.

1512.text: The graves, row upon row, the seemingly endless roll call of names

1517.text:
on the panels, all making
up the almost incalculable toll of the so-called

1531.text: Back in Ieper, there is a British church with more memorials

1539.text: Just off the main square in Ieper, you come across this church.

1543.text:
It’s, perhaps, rather unassuming by comparison
to some of the grand gothic buildings elsewhere

1547.text:
in the city. But this is a very important
place, it’s St George’s Memorial Church.

1552.text:
It was built after the First World War, and
it’s a living memorial to all those who

1557.text:
died, including those hundreds of thousands
from Yorkshire.

1563.text: Well, I’m joined by here by Canon Ray Jones, who is the Chaplain.

1567.text: Just tell me a little bit about this history of this church - how long has it been here?

1570.text: Well they started to raise funds in the mid 1920s.

1574.text:
And by 1927 they had enough money to start
the building. They bought the plot of… or,

1579.text:
the plot of land was both bought and
given by local people and the Royal British Legion

1584.text:
and one or two others. And, by 1929,
the building, designed by Sir Reginald Blomfield,

1590.text:
was completed and opened in July of 1929.
So, its main function is what: is to provide

1597.text:
a permanent memorial to those regiments, battalions,
companies, and, of course, the men in them

1603.text:
who died here. Indeed, yes, from the First
World War. And, of course, now we do intend

1608.text:
to include some Second World War people who
served in this area and before the capitulation,

1614.text:
as it were of the Belgians. And, of course,
schools come now to remember their pupils

1620.text:
who killed in the First World War particularly.
And… there’s a regular stream of visitors,

1625.text:
